The exact purpose of the Altamira Caves is not known, as prehistoric humans did not leave written records of their activities. However, archaeologists and historians have suggested several possible uses of the caves by prehistoric humans.

One theory is that the caves were used as living quarters or shelters. The caves would have provided protection from the elements and predators, as well as a source of freshwater from nearby springs. Some evidence of fire pits has been found in the caves, suggesting that prehistoric humans may have used fire for cooking and warmth.

Another theory is that the caves were used for religious or spiritual purposes. The elaborate and intricate cave paintings suggest that they were not simply decorative or artistic, but may have had symbolic or spiritual significance to prehistoric humans. Some scholars have suggested that the caves were used for rituals or ceremonies, and that the paintings may have represented deities or spirits.

Overall, the exact purpose of the Altamira Caves is not definitively known, but it is likely that prehistoric humans utilized the caves for a variety of purposes, including for art, shelter, and potentially for religious or spiritual activities.
